Joining us from the studios of Harvard University, Charles Ogletree, Harvard law professor, and Callie Crossley, social and cultural commentator on the television show ""Beat The Press"" seen in Boston.
Also joining us today, George Curry, editor in chief of the National Newspaper Publishers Association News Service.
He joins us from Maryland.
Before we get into those two issues, we want to take a little look back at the president's trip to Latin America.
Charles Ogletree, we talked about this on Friday.
I'm sure if the president had it to do all over again and if it would not have looked like a disaster, he may have pulled out of this.
It didn't seem with all the clouds at the White House right now this would have been the best trip for him.
Based on what we see, and certainly Hugo Chavez did not make it an easy trip for this president, is this just the nature of America today?
We have always been seen, quite frankly, as the world's police, but it seems as though there are those more willing to stand up and push, as they see, the bully about.
Well, Ed, I think you're right.
The problem is that we are sort of blind to the fact that worldwide, there's a lot of resentment to America's global politics or domination militarily and the lack of concern for the Third World.
And it is exploding all over South America.
It's not just Venezuela but in Argentina, in Brazil, in Peru.
We see the violence in France now among people of African descent.

So I think it's a wake-up call that when people have a chance to express themselves, there's a lot of hostility toward this country for not being more accommodating, understanding different cultures and nations and in being a bully.
And I think President Bush saw that with Chavez's incredibly energized speech at the stadium this weekend, and people are aware that America is not well-regarded around the world.
Callie, the idea that...
In addition...
Go ahead.
Go ahead.
I was going to say in addition to that, I would say that polls have just indicated that George Bush is the most unpopular president ever in Latin America.
So we have all of what Charles has said invested in this one guy as well.
How do you sit down at the table to have serious discussions about a serious issue like trade when you really are distrustful over the person representing the heaviest weight in the hemisphere?
And I think another point is, too, is that even the young democracies, Peru, Argentina, Bolivia, they really haven't delivered the goods as far as a lot of the grassroot peoples are concerned.
They're disenchanted because they haven't seen economic justice.
They haven't seen social justice.
And they're really not sold on this whole concept of democracy in terms of really improving their lives.
It also puts many of these countries in an interesting position.
We note that President Bush met with Brazilian President da Silva and they talked about the idea of the United States having to deal in trade talks and perhaps reduce American tariffs.

To a great degree, Charles Ogletree, they sit in a cat-bird seat that heretofore they did not sit in and probably have a little bit more negotiating power based on the want to reduce the rift between these countries and the United States.
Indeed.
And it's not just these countries, Ed.

If you think back just a few years, the same effort by leaders of these African and very diverse countries blew up during President Clinton's era--that is, the whole Caribbean region was concerned about tariffs, the banana trade, for example, that people were saying, `If you want to talk about security in our region, the only way we can make a living is to help us to get our products out.
The same thing's happened now in South America and I think our government will have to listen.
One of the great things the president said at least for my ears was that he supports the Organization of American States.
We have just filed a petition there for the Tulsa Race Riot Survivors.
So we'll see how much international law and economic justice is more than a few words but really an agenda of this administration in the coming months.
Callie, do you believe that?
Charles suggest that they'll have to take a look at those things.

There will be some who will say that this administration and political players in general in the United States have been so used to not having to look other places and to almost by divine intervention in their minds put down what they suggest is best for the world, i.e., best for America.
Do you believe that eventually they'll have to change the way they deal with others?
Absolutely.
I mean, we are in a global economy, period, and you've got to have some kind of conversation across the table.
You may not always agree, but there's going to have to be some consensus so that people interact.
And I think the fact that even though that we are a dominant force, these countries are saying, `Yeah, but we're not going to give you everything you want.
He could have walked away presumably and thought maybe he might, meaning Bush, with a signed statement of agreement by all these countries.
I thought, `Sit down.
We'll have a long conversation and we'll come away with something,' but he did not.
In fact, he's come away empty-handed and now the White House is trying to play that down.
But the bottom line is small though these countries may be, they are flexing their muscle and understanding that they do have something to offer and President Bush has got to pay attention to that.

And let's not forget that they still have the backing of the World Trade Organization, WTO, who basically agree that we have a lot of limits on what people can export here to this country, particularly oranges and sugar and cotton, and they want some more balance.
It'll be interesting to see what happens in Washington in terms of the want and need to change how one deals with these countries, as I said heretofore, really you just gave direction to.
You weren't used to sitting down and negotiating and talking and trying to hammer out agreements and future steps if you will.
Thank you, Ed.
Always a pleasure.
Thank you.
